summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney and defense attorney Christian Everdell regarding discovery production logistics in the case US v. Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The emails discuss technical issues with providing discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC, including hard drive capacity, file accessibility, and restrictions on her review time.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with the prosecution about discovery production logistics and access issues for his client.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in case 20 Cr. 330, held at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), whose access to discovery materials and review time is being negotiated.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on the email correspondence regarding discovery production.

events.title: Discovery Production Delivery
events.description: A hard drive containing a discovery production was delivered to the MDC for Ghislaine Maxwell, but she had not received it as of November 18.

events.title: Discovery Access Negotiations
events.description: Email correspondence reveals ongoing negotiations between prosecution and defense regarding Maxwell's access to discovery materials and review time restrictions at the MDC.

locations: One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The discovery production includes approximately 1.2 million documents, with the final portion of responsive images from Jeffrey Epstein's iPhone on a separate CD.
Ghislaine Maxwell's access to discovery review at the MDC was restricted to 7 hours per day (8:30am-3:30pm weekdays) instead of the previously agreed 13 hours per day plus weekends.
The prosecution provided a laptop to Maxwell for reviewing discovery, but it lacked sufficient storage, requiring her to use external hard drives that had experienced technical problems.
Defense attorney Christian Everdell expressed concerns that Maxwell could not possibly review over 2 million pages of discovery material by trial with the imposed time restrictions.
